> No, it does not require. I tried to do that, but found that JUnit
> does not use TestCase instance passed to suite.add() method. It just
> direves class name from the instance and them creates a new one to
> run test. I might be wrong, but I spent pretty much time and finally
> came up with the conslusion above.

I want to be clear: you mean to say that you pass a TestCase instance to 
suite.addTest(), then JUnit created a /different/ instance of the 
TestCase class when it ran the tests? That absolutely should not happen. 
If it did, the Parameterized Test Case pattern wouldn't work at all.

At this point, I'd need to see real code to be able to diagnose the problem.
